CONCLUSION: No violation of Art. 8;Violation of Art. 14+8;Violation of Art. 6-1;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - domestic proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant is a NORP national , born in DATE and living in PERSON . He is the father of the child PERSON , born out of wedlock on DATE . The applicant and the child ’s mother , PERSON , lived together at the time of the child ’s birth . They separated in DATE .
ORG mother married in DATE and ORG family name was changed to her mother ’s new family name .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG decided that the applicant should be entitled to visit his daughter . These visiting arrangements were confirmed in a court settlement between the parents in DATE . Under the terms of this settlement , the applicant was entitled to visit the child DATE . After some first visits , the applicant did no longer exercise his right of access to his daughter .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the child ’s mother applied with ORG for an amendment of the above settlement to the effect that the applicant should no longer be allowed access to his child . It was stated that the applicant had not exercised his right of access for DATE so that J. had completely forgotten him . His wish to see her again was not in J. ’s interest .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Jugendamt ) , having regard to a report by ORG , a NORP welfare organisation , recommended that the applicant should not be granted access to his child .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered that a medical report be prepared on the question of access . The report dated DATE recommended that contact between the applicant and J. be build up carefully and gradually , despite of the risk for J. ’s emotional balance . The established sound emotional ties between J. and her mother and the relationship of trust with the mother ’s partner should , however , not be upset .

CARDINAL . NORP In a further report of CARDINAL DATE , ORG recommended that the applicant should meet PERSON in a child guidance centre ( ORG ) . If these contacts developed positively , they should be extended or , in the event of a negative experience , access should be stopped . ORG shared this assessment .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG confirmed that , DATE and DATE , J. had met the applicant CARDINAL times in the centre in her mother ’s presence . It was stated that J. had sensed the conflicts between her parents and was under mounting emotional strain as a result .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG heard the applicant and PERSON ’s mother . In these and the following proceedings , both parties were represented by counsel .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG heard the then DATE child in the absence of her parents . She stated that she had not recognised her natural father and that she did not want to see him .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG set aside its earlier decision of DATE and the court settlement of DATE .

The court noted inter alia that the applicant had not exercised his right to visit his daughter since DATE and that ORG mother was opposed to the applicant ’s request . The court found that the applicant was not entitled to have access to his daughter .

Referring to section DATE of LAW ( Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch ) , the District court observed that the mother , in the exercise of her right to custody , determined the child ’s relations with third persons , and that therefore her will was decisive . The father could only be granted a right of access by court order if this was in the interest of the child . According to the court ’s findings , these conditions were not met in the applicant ’s case . The court considered that , as the parents separated when PERSON was only one and a half years old and as he did not exercise his right of access for DATE , he was a stranger in respect of the child . No bonds existed between her and the applicant and she did not regard him as her father .

ORG further considered that the attempt to overcome this situation had failed . It noted that , in the course of several meetings between the applicant and his daughter at an educational assistance office in DATE and DATE , he had remained a stranger to J. who did not wish to have contacts with her father . In the court ’s view , it was not in ORG interest to act contrary to her wish . After several changes , her mother ’s new husband had become a person exercising parental functions ( männliche PERSON ) . J. ’s stable position and emotions would be shaken if contacts with a stranger were forced . In this context , the court considered that PERSON was very sensitive and vulnerable and therefore needed stable living conditions and a family life free of conflict . Her physical and emotional well - being could be easily affected and she had difficulties in concentrating and learning . Her wish not to have any contacts with her father had , therefore , to be accepted .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal .

ORG endorsed ORG findings under section CARDINAL of LAW . ORG further found that the applicant ’s appeal submissions did not disclose any new elements that were relevant . His argument that it had not been his fault that he had not been able to exercise his right of access since DATE was irrelevant , as the child ’s interests were decisive . His criticism of section DATE was irrelevant as this provision was the applicable legislation according to which granting access contrary to the mother ’s will was only possible in the interest of the child . However , in the applicant ’s case ORG , on the basis of an expert opinion , had correctly found that ORG wish not to have contacts with the applicant had to be accepted . Moreover , even assuming that PERSON was influenced by her mother , such influence could not justify to force her to have contacts with the applicant . In this respect , ORG again noted the expert ’s findings that PERSON was very sensitive and vulnerable and that any forced contacts would certainly harm her .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared the applicant ’s further complaint inadmissible , pursuant to section CARDINALa of LAW ( Gesetz über die Angelegenheiten der freiwilligen PERSON ) . ORG considered that the prevailing legal situation , excluding a further appeal in proceedings concerning a father ’s access to his child born out of wedlock , could not be objected to from a constitutional point of view . Even if the criteria established in ORG decision of DATE on the necessity to abolish discrimination against children born out of wedlock were applied to procedural rules , the general standards as to the period left to the legislator for the purpose of amending the relevant legislation did not yet permit the conclusion that the existing legislation was unconstitutional .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed a constitutional complaint with ORG , complaining that the refusal of access to his daughter infringed his parental rights and amounted to discrimination , as well as about the refusal of his further appeal . ORG of the First Senate of ORG acknowledged receipt on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG informed the applicant ’s lawyer that it was dealing with a further case concerning section DATE of LAW which had already been submitted . A decision in that case was envisaged for DATE . The processing of the applicant ’s case was therefore postponed . On DATE , upon the applicant ’s inquiry , the Judge at ORG dealing with the applicant ’s case informed him that a decision on the other case was envisaged for DATE . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE , the applicant ’s representative was informed that the date of a decision upon his complaint could not be foreseen . The applicant was subsequently informed that , in the light of the legislative reforms , a decision on his constitutional complaint did no longer appear necessary and the applicant agreed to consider the complaint as settled .
The applicant ’s renewed request for access to J. remained unsuccessful .

CARDINAL . The statutory provisions on custody and access are to be found in the NORP Civil Code . They have been amended on several occasions and many were repealed by the amended LAW ) of DATE ( ORG , p. CARDINAL ) , which came into force on DATE .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL reads as follows ( the ORG ’s translation ) :

“ The father and the mother have the right and the duty to exercise parental authority ( elterliche PERSON ) over a minor child . The parental authority includes the custody ( PERSON ) and the care of property ( Vermögenssorge ) of the child . ”

CARDINAL . Pursuant to section CARDINAL a § CARDINAL , as amended , the parents of a minor child born out of wedlock jointly exercise custody if they make a declaration to that effect ( declaration on joint custody ) or if they marry . According to LAW , as amended , a child is entitled to have access to both parents ; each parent is obliged to have contact with , and entitled to have access to , the child . Moreover , the parents must not do anything that would harm the child ’s relationship with the other parent or seriously interfere with the child ’s upbringing . The family courts can determine the scope of the right of access and prescribe more specific rules for its exercise , also with regard to third parties ; and they may order the parties to fulfil their obligations towards the child . The family courts can , however , restrict or suspend that right if such a measure is necessary for the child ’s welfare . A decision restricting or suspending that right for a lengthy period or permanently may only be taken if otherwise the child ’s well - being would be endangered . The family courts may order that the right of access exercised in the presence of a third party , such as a ORG authority or an association .

CARDINAL . NORP Before the entry into force of the amended Law on Family Matters , the relevant provision of LAW concerning custody and access for a child born in wedlock was worded as follows ( the ORG ’s translation ) :
Section CARDINAL

“ CARDINAL . A parent not having custody has the right to personal contact with the child . The parent not having custody and the person having custody must not do anything that would harm the child ’s relationship with others or seriously interfere with the child ’s upbringing .

CARDINAL . The family court can determine the scope of that right and can prescribe more specific rules for its exercise , also with regard to third parties ; as long as no decision is made , the right , under section CARDINAL § CARDINAL , of the parent not having custody may be exercised throughout the period of contact . The family court can restrict or suspend that right if such a measure is necessary for the child ’s welfare .

CARDINAL . A parent not having custody who has a legitimate interest in obtaining information about the child ’s personal circumstances may request such information from the person having custody in so far as this is in keeping with the child ’s interests . The guardianship court shall rule on any dispute over the right to information .
CARDINAL . Where both parents have custody and are separated not merely temporarily , the foregoing provisions shall apply mutatis mutandis . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW concerning custody of and access to a child born out of wedlock were worded as follows ( the ORG ’s translation ) :
Section CARDINAL
“ Custody over a minor child born out of wedlock is exercised by the child ’s mother ... ”
Section CARDINAL
“ CARDINAL . The person having custody of the child shall determine the father ’s right of access to the child . Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL , second sentence , applies by analogy .

CARDINAL . If it is in the child ’s interests to have personal contact with the father , the guardianship court can decide that the father has a right to personal contact . Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL applies by analogy . The guardianship court can change its decision at any time .
CARDINAL . The right to request information about the child ’s personal circumstances is set out in LAW § CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . Where appropriate , the youth office shall mediate between the father and the person who exercises the right of custody . ”
CARDINAL . Like proceedings in other family matters , proceedings under former section DATE LAW were governed by LAW ( PERSON über die ORG der freiwilligen PERSON ) .

CARDINAL . According to section CARDINAL of that Act , the court shall , ex officio , take the measures of investigation that are necessary to establish the relevant facts and take the evidence that appears appropriate .
CARDINAL . In proceedings regarding access , the competent youth office has to be heard prior to the decision ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ( k ) ) .

CARDINAL . As regards the hearing of parents in custody proceedings , section ORG ( CARDINAL ) stipulates that the court shall hear the parents in proceedings concerning custody or the administration of the child ’s assets . In matters relating to custody , the court shall , as a rule , hear the parents personally . In cases concerning placement into public care , the parents shall always be heard . According to paragraph CARDINAL of section CARDINALa , a parent not having custody shall be heard except where it appears that such a hearing would not contribute to the clarification of the matter .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provides for a right of a further appeal challenging the first appeal decision . Section CARDINALa of that Act as in force at the material time excluded this right in proceedings concerning a natural father ’s access to his child born out of wedlock . This provision has been repealed by ORG .
